facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 225, 226, 228, 229 and 248 of 1955 were heard together by the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeals Nos. 225, 226, 228, 229 and 248 of 1955. Appeals from the judgments and orders dated October 5, 1953, in Misc. Judicial Cases Nos. 418/52 and 124/53 and October 8, 1953., in T. S. No. 106/53, Misc. Judicial Cases Nos. 188/53 and 235/53 of the Patna High Court.

facts.text: Appeals arise from judgments and orders of Patna High Court dated October 5, 1953 in Misc. Judicial Cases Nos. 418/52 and 124/53 and October 8, 1953 in T.S. No. 106/53, Misc. Judicial Cases Nos. 188/53 and 235/53.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgments and orders dated October 5, 1953, in Misc. Judicial Cases Nos. 418/52 and 124/53 and October 8, 1953., in T. S. No. 106/53, Misc. Judicial Cases Nos. 188/53 and 235/53 of the Patna High Court. Patnaik, for the appellant  in C. A. No. 225/55 . C.Prasad, for the appellants  in C. As. Nos. 226, 228, 229 248/55 .

facts.text: Judgment of the Supreme Court delivered on April 15, 1959 by K. DAS, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1959. April 15. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by K. DAS, J.-This is a batch of five appeals which have been heard together and the principal question for decision in these appeals is the companystitutional validity of the Bihar Hindu Religious Trusts Act,, 1950  Bihar I of 1951 , hereinafter referred to as the Act.

facts.text: Four appeals arise out of writ proceedings under Articles 226 and 227 of the Constitution in Patna High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Four of these appeals arise out of writ proceedings taken in the High Court of Patna on petitions made under Arts. 226 and 227 of the Constitution. One of them, namely, Civil Appeal No. 228 of 1955, arises out of a suit which was originally instituted in the Court of the Subordinate Judge of Patna but was later transferred to the High Court by an order made by it tinder Art. 228 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 228 of 1955 arises from a suit originally instituted in the Court of the Subordinate Judge of Patna and transferred to High Court under Article 228.

anchor.surface_text: One of them, namely, Civil Appeal No. 228 of 1955, arises out of a suit which was originally instituted in the Court of the Subordinate Judge of Patna but was later transferred to the High Court by an order made by it tinder Art. 228 of the Constitution. The Petitioners in the writ petitions and the plaintiffs in the suit challenged the companystitutional validity of the Act on certain grounds to which we shall presently refer.

facts.text: Patna High Court held the Bihar Hindu Religious Trusts Act, 1950 valid and dismissed writ petitions and suit on October 5 and 8, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court in three separate judgments, two dated October 5, 1953, and the third dated October 8, 1953, held that the Act was a valid piece of legislation and on that main finding dismissed the writ petitions and the suit.

facts.text: Appellants obtained certificates from Patna High Court under Article 132 for appeals to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners and the plaintiff-,, appellants before us, applied for and obtained certificates from the High Court under Art. 132 of the Constitution to the effect that the cases involved substantial ques- tions of law as to the interpretation of the Constitution and the appeals have been brought to this Court in pursuance of those certificates.

facts.text: Mahant Moti Das is Mahant of math or asthal in village Parbatta, district Monghyr, Bihar, follower of religion founded by Sri Kabir Sahib.

anchor.surface_text: In Civil Appeal No. 225 of 1955 the appellant is Mahant Moti Das, and he alleged that he was the Mahant of a math or astral situate in village Parbatta, district Monghyr, in Bihar, that he was a follower of the religion founded by Sri Kabir Sahib, that the properties of the asthal were treated as private properties of the mahants

facts.text: President of Bihar State Board of Religious Trusts served notice under s.59 of the Act on Mahant Moti Das.

anchor.surface_text: and that the President of the Bihar State Board of Religious Trusts companystituted under the Act had numberauthority to serve him with a numberice under s. 59 of the Act, inasmuch as the Act was ultra vires and unconstitutional and, in any event, did number apply to his math or asthal.

facts.text: Mahant Ram Das is mahant of math or asthal in village Bhuthari, district Monghyr, Bihar, bairagi sadhu and follower of Ramanandi Laskari Sri Vaishnava Sampradaya.

anchor.surface_text: In Civil Appeal No. 226 of 1955 the appellant Mahant Ram Das similarly alleged that he was the mahant of a math or asthal situate in village Bhuthari in the same district of Monghyr, that he was a bairagi sadhu and follower of Ramanandi Laskari Sri Vaishnava Sampradaya, that he was the absolute owner of the properties belonging to the math

facts.text: President, Bihar State Board of Religious Trusts issued notice to Mahant Ram Das to furnish statements and accounts of properties.

anchor.surface_text: and that the President, Bihar State Board of Religious Trusts, had numberauthority to issue a numberice to him asking him to furnish statements and accounts of the properties in his possession.

facts.text: Mahant Mahabir Das is Mahant of Bisanpur Asthal in district Monghyr.

anchor.surface_text: In Civil Appeal No. 229 of 1955 the appellant Mahant Mahabir Das stated that he was the Mahant of a asthal known as Bisanpur Asthal situate in the self- same district. He also received a numberice from the President, Bihar State Board of Religious Trusts, to furnish statements and accounts,

facts.text: Mahant Mahabir Das received notice from President, Bihar State Board of Religious Trusts to furnish statements and accounts.

anchor.surface_text: He also received a numberice from the President, Bihar State Board of Religious Trusts, to furnish statements and accounts, and he challenged the vires of the Act on similar grounds.

facts.text: Temple Bhikam as Thakurbari in Patba constructed by Benidasji with his own money and deities installed therein.

anchor.surface_text: In Civil Appeal No. 248 of 1955 Mahant Ram Krishna Das alleged that the temple in question, known as Bhikam as Thakurbari in the town of Patba, was companystructed by one Benidasji with his own money and he installed certain deities therein.

facts.text: Bihar Hindu Religious Trusts Act, 1950 (Bihar I of 1951) received assent of President published in Bihar Gazette on February 21, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The Act was passed by the Bihar Legislature and received the assent of the President,, which assent was published in the Bihar Gazette on February 21, 1951. The long title of the Act and the preamble give the object of the Act.

facts.text: Bihar Hindu Religious Trusts Act came into force on August 15, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Section I gives the short title, and provides for extent and companymencement, the Act having companye into force on August 15, 1951.

facts.text: Supreme Court held Bihar Hindu Religious Trusts Act constitutionally valid.

anchor.surface_text: We have held that the Act is companystitutionally valid.

facts.text: Questions whether trusts are public or private require investigation of facts and evidence, not decided in writ proceedings by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: In all these cases the High Court has taken the view, rightly in our opinion, that the questions whether the trusts are public or private trusts or the properties are private or trust properties are questions which involve investigation of companyplicated facts and recording of evidence and such investigation companyld number be done on writ proceedings.

facts.text: In CA 225/55, State of Bihar filed counter-affidavit that asthal is public and properties trust properties.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has pointed out that in M. J. C. 418 of 1952 out of which has arisen Civil Appeal No. 225 of 1955, though there was an assertion that the properties were number trust properties, there was a companynter-affidavit on behalf of the State of Bihar that the asthal in question was a public asthal and the properties appertaining thereto trust properties within the meaning of the Act.

issues.text: the principal question for decision in these appeals is the constitutional validity of the Bihar Hindu Religious Trusts Act, 1950 (Bihar I of 1951), hereinafter referred to as the Act

anchor.surface_text: the principal question for decision in these appeals is the constitutional validity of the Bihar Hindu Religious Trusts Act, 1950 (Bihar I of 1951), hereinafter referred to as the Act. Four of these appeals arise out of writ proceedings taken in the High Court of Patna on petitions made under Arts. 226 and 227 of the Constitution.

issues.text: whether the provisions in ss. 2, 5, 6, 7 and 8 infringe Art. 14 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: The first contention is that the provisions in ss. 2, 5, 6, 7 and 8 infringe Art. 14 of the Constitution. It is pointed out that the definition of the word Hindu in s. 2 does not include Sikhs and s. 5 constitutes a Board for religious trusts other than Jain religious trusts,

issues.text: whether the provisions in Chapter V, and in particular ss. 28 and 32, violate the fundamental right guaranteed to the appellants under Art. 19(1)(f) of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: The next contention urged on behalf of the appellants is that the provisions in Chapter V, and in particular ss. 28 and 32, violate the fundamental right guaranteed to the appellants under Art. 19 1 f of the Constitution, namely, their right to acquire, hold and dispose of the trust properties.

issues.text: whether any of the provisions of the Act interfere with the rights guaranteed by Arts. 25 and 26 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: The third contention of the appellants rests upon Arts. 25 and 26 of the Constitution. The appellants have invoked in aid Art. 25 1 which says inter alia, that subject to public order, morality and health, all persons have the right freely to profess, practice and propagate religion.

issues.text: whether s. 70 of the Act imposes an unauthorised tax and contravenes Art. 27 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: Lastly, the appellants have challenged the validity of s. 70 of the Act,the relevant portion of which states expenses incurred or to be incurred in the administration of this Act, the trustee of every religious trust shall, in each financial year, pay to the Board such fee,

issues.text: whether s. 55(2) of the Act contravenes Art. 133 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: It has also been argued that s. 55 2 of the Act contravenes Art. 133 of the Constitution and is accordingly invalid. Section 55 is in these terms 55 1 . Unless otherwise provided in this Act, an appeal shall lie to the High Court against every order passed by the District Judge under this Act.

issues.text: whether the properties in question are private properties or private trusts not covered by the Act

anchor.surface_text: We now come to that part of the case of the appellants in which they claim the properties to be their private properties or, in the alternative, the trusts to be private trusts. The High Court has pointed out that in M. J. C. 418 of 1952...

arguments.claim: Provisions in ss. 2, 5, 6, 7 and 8 infringe Art. 14 due to unreasonable classification excluding Sikhs and differential treatment for Jain trusts

anchor.surface_text: The first contention is that the provisions in ss. 2, 5, 6, 7 and 8 infringe Art. 14 of the Constitution. It is pointed out that the definition of the word Hindu in s. 2 does not include Sikhs and s. 5 constitutes a Board for religious trusts other than Jain religious trusts, and also two separate Boards-one for Swetambar Jain religious trusts and the other for Digambar Jain religious trusts.

arguments.court_reasoning: Classification founded on intelligible differentia (differences in faith, practices, organization) with rational relation to object of better administration; presumption of constitutionality; cites precedents on reasonable classification.

arguments.claim: Classification under the Act satisfies Art. 14 as reasonable with intelligible differentia and rational nexus
Provisions in Chapter V, particularly ss. 28 and 32, violate Art. 19(1)(f) by imposing unreasonable restrictions on right to hold and dispose trust properties

anchor.surface_text: The next contention urged on behalf of the appellants is that the provisions in Chapter V, and in particular ss. 28 and 32, violate the fundamental right guaranteed to the appellants under Art. 19(1)(f) of the Constitution, namely, their right to acquire, hold and dispose of the trust properties.

arguments.court_reasoning: Restrictions reasonable under Art.19(5) for better administration, protection of trusts; safeguards like appeals; distinguishes Shirur Mutt and Orissa cases.

arguments.claim: Restrictions in Act on trustees' powers are reasonable under Art.19(5) for general public interest in trust administration

anchor.surface_text: This argument before us has proceeded on the footing that the properties which the appellants hold are trust properties within the meaning of the Act but we must state here that the appellants have also alleged that the properties are their private properties, to which aspect of the case we shall advert later.

arguments.claim: Provisions of Act interfere with rights under Arts. 25 and 26 to profess, practice religion and manage religious affairs

anchor.surface_text: The third contention of the appellants rests upon Arts. 25 and 26 of the Constitution. The appellants have invoked in aid Art. 25(1) which says inter alia, that subject to public order, morality and health, all persons have the right freely to profess, practice and propagate religion.

arguments.claim: Act does not violate Arts. 25 or 26 as it ensures proper administration without diverting from religious purposes

anchor.surface_text: Article 26 is also relied on for the contention that every religious denomination or any section thereof has a right (a) to establish and maintain institutions for religious and charitable purposes and (b) to manage its own affairs in matters of religion.

anchor.surface_text: The argument is that s. 70 imposes an unauthorised tax. The point is, we think, concluded by our decision in Mahant Sri Jagannath Ramanuj Das v. The State of Orissa where the distinction between a tax and a fee for legislative purposes under our Constitution was pointed out

anchor.surface_text: It has also been argued that s. 55(2) of the Act contravenes Art. 133 of the Constitution and is accordingly invalid. Section 55 is in these terms 55(1). Unless otherwise provided in this Act, an appeal shall lie to the High Court against every order passed by the District Judge under this Act.

arguments.court_reasoning: Does not override constitutional jurisdiction of Supreme Court.

arguments.claim: s.55(2) does not affect Supreme Court appellate jurisdiction under Art.133

anchor.surface_text: We do not think that s. 55(2) of the Act overrides or is intended to override Art. 133 or any other Article of the Constitution relating to appeals to the Supreme Court. Such appeals must undoubtedly lie to the Supreme Court, provided the necessary requirements for such appeals are fulfilled.

arguments.claim: Questions of public vs private trusts require factual investigation, not decidable in writ/suit proceedings

anchor.surface_text: In all these cases the High Court has taken the view, rightly in our opinion, that the questions whether the trusts are public or private trusts or the properties are private or trust properties are questions which involve investigation of complicated facts and recording of evidence and such investigation could not be done on writ proceedings.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: religion or of any denomination within it the purpose is to see that religious trusts and institutions wherever they exist are properly administered.

arguments.claim: Bihar Hindu Religious Trusts Act is constitutionally valid

anchor.surface_text: We have held that the Act is constitutionally valid.

arguments.claim: Act valid and applies to the asthals/temples and properties

anchor.surface_text: The defence in all these cases was that the Act was valid, and applied to the asthals or temple in question and the properties thereof.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: 5 there was a companynter-affidavit on behalf of the State of Bihar that the temple in question was

arguments.court_reasoning: Validity accepted; applicability to specific trusts not decided on facts.

holdings.text: The Bihar Hindu Religious Trusts Act, 1950 is constitutionally valid.

anchor.surface_text: We have held that the Act is constitutionally valid.

holdings.reasoning_summary: After rejecting all constitutional challenges under Arts.14,19(1)(f),25,26,27,133, court concludes Act valid as reasonable restrictions for trust administration.

holdings.text: Provisions in ss.2,5,6,7,8 do not infringe Art.14 as classification excluding Sikhs and distinguishing Jains is reasonable.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, the contention urged on behalf of the appellants that the several provisions of the Act contravene Art. 14 is devoid of any merit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Classification based on intelligible differentia in faith, practices, organization of Hindus/Sikhs/Jains with rational nexus to administration object; presumption of constitutionality; follows Dalmia precedent.

holdings.text: Restrictions in Chapter V (ss.28,32) on trustees are reasonable under Art.19(5) and do not violate Art.19(1)(f).

anchor.surface_text: they are, therefore, reasonable restrictions in the interests of the general public within the meaning of cl. 5 of Art. 19 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Powers for supervision, schemes etc. for better administration/protection of trusts with safeguards like appeals; shebait rights subject to public interest; distinguishes Shirur Mutt/Orissa cases.

holdings.text: Provisions of Act do not interfere with rights under Arts.25 and 26.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, there is no substance in the argument that the provisions of the Act contravene Arts. 25 and 26 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No impact on profess/practice religion or manage affairs; powers respect founders' wishes/trust objects; prevents mismanagement without diverting purposes; follows Shirur Mutt.

holdings.text: s.70 imposes a fee, not tax, and does not contravene Art.27.

anchor.surface_text: We are further of opinion that an imposition like this cannot be said to be hit by article 27 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Fee for specific administration expenses, not general revenue/promoting religion; follows Orissa case precedent on identical provision.

anchor.surface_text: We do not think that s. 55(2) of the Act overrides or is intended to override Art. 133 or any other Article of the Constitution relating to appeals to the Supreme Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory provision cannot override constitutional appellate jurisdiction if requirements fulfilled.

holdings.text: Questions whether trusts/properties public or private require factual investigation/evidence, not decidable in writ proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: In all these cases the High Court has taken the view, rightly in our opinion, that the questions whether the trusts are public or private trusts or the properties are private or trust properties are questions which involve investigation of complicated facts and recording of evidence and such investigation could not be done on writ proceedings.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agrees with High Court; factual disputes need evidence, unsuitable for summary writ jurisdiction.

precedents.citation: Shri Ram Krishna Dalmia v. Shri Justice S. R. Tendolkar 1

anchor.surface_text: see the cases referred to in Shri Ram Krishna Dalmia v. Shri Justice S. R. Tendolkar 1 . It is, therefore, unnecessary to enter upon any lengthy discussion as to the meaning, scope and effect of the Article. It is enough to say that it is number well settled by a series of decisions of this Court that while Art. 14 forbids class legislation, it does number forbid reasonable classification for the purposes of legislation, and in order to pass the test of permissible classification, two companyditions must be fulfilled, namely,  1  that the classification must be founded on an intelligible differential which distinguishes persons or things that are grouped together from others left out of the group and  2  that differentia must have a rational relation to the object sought to be achieved by the statute in question.

precedents.cited_proposition: meaning, scope and effect of Art. 14 of the Constitution; permits reasonable classification founded on intelligible differentia with rational relation to object

The State of Bombay in which it has been held that a religious sect or denomination has the right to manage its own affairs in matters of religion and this includes the right to spend the trust property or its income for religion and for religious purposes and objects indicated by the founder of the trust or established by usage obtaining in a particular institution.
